questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isograft

 

An isograft is a type of graft where the donor and the recipient are genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of graft has the lowest risk of rejection because the donor and recipient have the same genetic makeup, which means their tissues are immunologically compatible.

 

Types of Grafts:

 

Option A. Allograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of the same species but have different genotypes.
  • Examples: Organ transplants between two different individuals (e.g., kidney transplant from one person to another non-twin individual).

 

Option B. Autograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are the same person.
  • Examples: Skin grafts taken from one part of the body and transplanted to another part of the same individual's body.

 

Option C. Isograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft between two individuals who are genetically identical, such as identical twins.
  • Examples: Organ or tissue transplants between identical twins.

 

Option D. Xenograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of different species.
  • Examples: Transplantation of animal tissues or organs into humans, such as pig heart valves used in human heart surgery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Autografts are grafts in which both the donor and the recipient are the same person.
  • Isografts are grafts that occur between donors and recipients who share the same genotype. An isograft is a graft from an identical twin
  • Allografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of the same species but of a different genotype.
  • Xenografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of different species.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of diarrhea

 

Diarrhea cannot reliably differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms of arthritis because it can be present in multiple arthritic conditions. Diarrhea could indicate:

 

  • Reactive arthritis following gastrointestinal infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis
  • Post-viral arthritis
  • Other forms of seronegative spondyloarthropathies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enthesitis:

 

  • Enthesitis (inflammation at sites where tendons/ligaments insert into bone) is a characteristic feature of psoriatic arthritis
  • It helps differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms like rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option C. Dactylitis:

 

  • Dactylitis ("sausage digits") is highly characteristic of psoriatic arthritis
  • Represents inflammation of the entire digit with soft tissue swelling
  • Helps differentiate from other forms where dactylitis is uncommon

 

Option D. Nail pitting:

 

  • Nail changes are seen in 80–90% of psoriatic arthritis patients
  • Nail pitting is a characteristic finding that helps distinguish psoriatic arthritis
  • A valuable diagnostic feature when present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enthesitis, dactylitis, and nail changes are characteristic features that help diagnose psoriatic arthritis. Diarrhea is a nonspecific symptom that can occur in multiple forms of arthritis and cannot be used as a differentiating feature.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

 

If the height for age of a child is less than -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population, it is most likely due to chronic malnutrition.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Malnutrition (Stunting): Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, occurs when a child does not receive adequate nutrition over a prolonged period, especially during the critical first 1,000 days of life (from conception to the child's second birthday). This results in impaired linear growth, making the child shorter than expected for their age. Height for age is the key indicator used to measure stunting.
  • Acute Malnutrition (Wasting): Acute malnutrition, or wasting, is characterized by a rapid loss of weight relative to height. It is usually the result of a recent illness or severe food shortage. Weight for height is the primary measure of wasting, not height for age.
  • Recent Infection: While a recent infection can temporarily affect a child's weight or growth velocity, it does not typically lead to chronic stunting unless the child experiences recurrent infections over a long period.
  • No Malnutrition: If a child's height for age is within the normal range, it indicates adequate nutrition and growth. However, a height for age < -2SD indicates a significant deviation from the norm due to chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute malnutrition: This condition affects the weight for height parameter, indicating a rapid loss of weight rather than a prolonged deficit in linear growth.

 

Option C. Recent infection: Although a recent infection can cause temporary weight loss or affect growth velocity, it is unlikely to result in stunted growth unless the child has had recurrent infections over an extended period.

 

Option D. No malnutrition: A child with a height for age < -2SD cannot be classified as having no malnutrition, as this deviation indicates chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. For intubation, 90 mg of rocuronium was given, but the anesthesiologist was unable to intubate the patient. What is the drug given for immediate reversal of the neuromuscular blockade? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sugammadex

 

Sugammadex is specifically designed to reverse the effects of rocuronium and vecuronium, which are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents used during anesthesia. Rocuronium works by blocking acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. Sugammadex, a γ-cyclodextrin compound, encapsulates the rocuronium molecules, effectively removing them from the neuromuscular junction. This action results in the immediate reversal of muscle paralysis, allowing the patient to regain normal muscle function. Sugammadex is unique because it can rapidly reverse the effects of rocuronium, even if the drug was administered only moments earlier, which is crucial in situations where intubation fails and the patient needs to recover quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is used to reverse non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like rocuronium, but it is not effective immediately after the drug has been administered. Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, thereby increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction to outcompete the blocking agent. However, for neostigmine to be effective, a significant amount of the neuromuscular blocking agent must have already dissociated from the receptors, which typically happens toward the end of the surgery, not immediately after administration.

 

Option C. Glycopyrrolate: Glycopyrrolate is often used in conjunction with neostigmine to counteract the muscarinic side effects of increased acetylcholine, such as bradycardia. However, glycopyrrolate itself does not reverse neuromuscular blockade and cannot be used to immediately counteract the effects of rocuronium.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine, like glycopyrrolate, is used to mitigate the side effects of cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. It does not reverse neuromuscular blockade directly and is not effective in immediately reversing the effects of rocuronium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the specific and immediate antidote for the reversal of rocuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade. It is unique in its ability to rapidly and effectively reverse paralysis even shortly after rocuronium administration, making it the drug of choice in emergency situations where rapid recovery of muscle function is required.

questions.text: Which of the following organism is intrinsically resistant to the given drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida krusei: Fluconazole

 

  • Candida krusei is known to have intrinsic resistance to fluconazole, which means that this organism generally does not respond to treatment with fluconazole. This is due to a combination of mechanisms including alterations in the target enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, efflux pump activity, and changes in membrane sterols. Therefore, for infections caused by Candida krusei, alternative antifungal agents such as amphotericin B, echinocandins, or voriconazole are typically considered.
  • In the clinical setting, the intrinsic resistance of Candida krusei to fluconazole is significant, as fluconazole is often used as a first-line agent for the treatment of Candida infections. The presence of Candida krusei may therefore necessitate a shift in the standard therapeutic approach and prompt the use of different antifungal therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus niger: Voriconazole Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that is effective against most species of Aspergillus, including Aspergillus niger. It is often used as a first-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis. Therefore, Aspergillus niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Micafungin Aspergillus fumigatus is generally susceptible to micafungin. Micafungin belongs to the echinocandin class of antifungal drugs, which are effective against most Aspergillus species, but echinocandins are not the first choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. They are typically used as second-line agents or in combination therapy for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option C. Candida glabrata: Amphotericin B Candida glabrata can be susceptible to amphotericin B, but it is known for having a dose-dependent sensitivity or a reduced susceptibility. Some strains may show resistance, but this is not considered intrinsic resistance. Instead, amphotericin B resistance in C. glabrata can be due to acquired mechanisms.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, necessitating the use of alternative antifungal agents for treatment.

choices.text: Allergic Interstitial Nephritis
Urinary Tract Infection

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with follicular tonsillitis, for which antibiotics were prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allergic Interstitial Nephritis

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), also known as drug-induced interstitial nephritis, is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by medications such as antibiotics (e.g., penicillins). The clinical presentation of AIN typically includes:

 

  • Recent medication use: In this case, antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis.
  • Flank pain and rash: These symptoms often develop a few days after starting the medication.
  • Eosinophilia: Elevated levels of eosinophils in peripheral blood are a hallmark of allergic reactions.
  • Urinalysis findings: Presence of white blood cell (WBC) casts in the urine indicates renal involvement.

 

The combination of these symptoms and laboratory findings strongly suggests allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever, unilateral flank pain, and urinary symptoms like dysuria. It is usually associated with bacterial infection, not with recent antibiotic use or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Berger Disease (IgA Nephropathy): IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, is a glomerulonephritis characterized by hematuria and sometimes proteinuria. It does not typically present with rash, eosinophilia, or WBC casts.

 

Option D. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): A UTI would present with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. It can also lead to pyelonephritis, but it does not typically cause eosinophilia or WBC casts in the absence of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis is characterized by recent medication use (such as antibiotics), flank pain, rash, eosinophilia, and WBC casts in urine. It is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by drugs, particularly antibiotics.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric adenocarcinoma

 

Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: This is a neuroendocrine tumor.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Represents a type of blood cancer originating from lymphocytes.

 

Option C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: A non-epithelial tumor that arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During endoscopy, the endoscope has reached 25 cm from the incisor teeth. The endoscope has reached till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, the distance from the incisor teeth to various anatomical landmarks in the esophagus is measured in centimeters. The esophagus is a muscular tube that passes through the thorax to the stomach. The significant landmarks that the endoscope passes as it moves down include the pharyngo-esophageal junction, the arch of the aorta, the left bronchus, and finally the diaphragm.

 

At 25 cm from the incisor teeth, the endoscope reaches the level of the arch of aorta. This is anatomically located around the T4 vertebra level. The arch of aorta causes a slight indentation in the esophagus, which is why it's a key point of reference during endoscopy.

 

 

 

Cricopharyngeal junction - C6 – 6” (15 cm)

 

Arch of aorta - T4 – 9” (22.5 cm)

 

Left bronchus - T6 – 11” (27.5 cm)

 

Diaphragm - T10 – 15” (37.5 cm)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left bronchus: The left bronchus is located slightly below the arch of aorta, typically around 27.5 cm from the incisor teeth, corresponding to the T6 vertebra level. Therefore, at 25 cm, the endoscope has not yet reached the left bronchus.

 

Option B. Main bronchus: The term "main bronchus" is often a general term that could refer to either the left or right bronchus. However, anatomically, both bronchi are located below the level of the arch of aorta, making this option incorrect for the 25 cm mark.

 

Option C. Right bronchus: The right bronchus, similar to the left, is located at a point beyond 25 cm from the incisor teeth, typically after the endoscope has passed the level of the arch of aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At 25 cm from the incisor teeth during an endoscopy, the endoscope has reached the level of the arch of aorta. This is a crucial anatomical landmark and is typically located at the T4 vertebra level

questions.text: Where will be the level of the uterus 48 hours after delivery?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2.5 cm below umbilicus

 

  • Following delivery, the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus
  • it remains at level of umbilicus for 24 hours. Following this, it involutes
  • It involutes 1.25 cm/ day form the 2nd day onwards
  • So, after 48 hours (2 days) post-delivery, the uterus will be felt 2.5 cm breadth below the umbilicus
  • It becomes a pelvic organ (no longer abdominally palpable) by 10-14 days
  • It becomes the size of a non-pregnant uterus by 6 weeks
  • alternatively, it reduces by 1 finger breadth / day from 2nd day post partum, till it becomes pelvic organ by 10-14 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterus will be 2.5 cm below umbilicus on the second-day post-delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 169, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Cannot comment without d-dimer values

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High

 

The Well's Score is a clinical tool used to estimate the probability of a pulmonary embolism (PE). The score is calculated based on various risk factors and clinical features. In this patient's case:

 

Modified wells criteria: 3 + 3 + 1.5 = 7.5 (>4) suggestive of high risk.

 

 

Inference:

 

  • 4: PE Likely
  • < 4: PE unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When assessing the risk of pulmonary embolism, especially in postoperative patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of DVT, it is essential to consider both the clinical presentation and the surgical history. The Wells score is a valuable tool in stratifying the risk and guiding further diagnostic testing and management. In this scenario, the patient falls into a high-risk category, indicating that further immediate investigation, typically with imaging like a CT pulmonary angiogram, is warranted.

 

Reference - UpToDate/Wells score

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: A child presented to PHC OPD with skin rash and depigmented hair. He gives a history of swollen/bleeding gums. X-ray picture is shown below. He is suffering from: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Copper deficiency


The clinical presentation of the child, including skin rash, depigmented hair, swollen/bleeding gums, and the X-ray findings, suggests a deficiency that closely mimics scurvy (vitamin C deficiency). However, in this question, the exact cause is copper deficiency, which shares similar symptoms and radiological appearances with scurvy. Copper plays a crucial role in various metabolic pathways, including those influenced by vitamin C, such as collagen synthesis and connective tissue health. Copper deficiency is known as pseudoscurvy because it presents with nearly identical clinical and radiological features as vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zinc deficiency: Zinc deficiency typically presents with symptoms such as delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, and dermatitis, particularly around orifices. It does not cause the specific combination of bleeding gums, depigmented hair, and the radiological changes observed in the X-ray.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency usually presents with symptoms related to anemia, such as fatigue, pallor, and pica. While it can cause brittle nails and hair changes, it does not present with bleeding gums and specific X-ray findings as seen in this case.

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency: Selenium deficiency primarily affects the heart and muscles, leading to conditions like Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy) and muscle weakness. It does not cause the bleeding gums, depigmented hair, or the bone abnormalities observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Copper deficiency can mimic vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) in its clinical and radiological presentation, a condition often referred to as pseudoscurvy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the trauma center after RTA with shortness of breath. The supine CXR is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemothorax

 

The provided supine chest X-ray (CXR) shows a generalized opacity throughout the left hemithorax, which is characteristic of a hemothorax. In a trauma setting, chest X-rays are often taken in the supine position because the patient cannot stand. In this position, the fluid from a hemothorax gravitates and spreads out across the thoracic cavity, leading to a uniform opacity on the affected side.

 

Hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, often occurs due to trauma and presents with symptoms of shortness of breath. The key radiographic feature on a supine CXR is the diffuse opacity without a typical meniscus sign, which is seen in erect chest X-rays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: This condition presents with hyperlucency (increased radiolucency) in the affected hemithorax. In a supine CXR, a deep sulcus sign might be seen, but there is no hyperlucency present in the image, ruling out pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Pulmonary contusion: Pulmonary contusions appear as localized areas of consolidation. They do not typically cause uniform opacity throughout an entire hemithorax as seen in this image.

 

Option D. Diaphragm injury: Diaphragm injuries can result in the presence of bowel loops within the thoracic cavity, which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a supine chest X-ray of a trauma patient, a hemothorax presents as a diffuse opacity throughout the affected hemithorax due to the gravitational spread of blood in the pleural space.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

 

The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

 

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is viral in origin and is caused by human papilloma virus type 6 and 11.
  • It is presumed that affected children got the disease at birth from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus disease.
  • Papilloma’s mostly affect supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can also involve subglottis, trachea and bronchi. DNA virus particles have been found in the cells of the basement membrane of respiratory mucosa and may account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Patients, often a child, between the age of 3 and 5 years present with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or even stridor.
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and later confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Papillomas are known for recurrence but rarely undergo malignant change.
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament. Other modalities of tumor removal are with cold steel instruments or  debrider or coblation or radiofrequency. Aim of therapy is to maintain a good airway, preserve voice and avoid recurrence.
  • Adjuvant medical therapies include Interferon alpha-2a and 13-cis-retinoic acid has been used.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Reinke's edema - Characterized by swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation, not similar to the warty growths of papillomas.

 

Option B. Malignancy - Would typically appear more irregular and could involve more invasive growth patterns.

 

Option C. Tracheomalacia - A condition related to the softening of the tracheal walls, not relevant to laryngeal lesions.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 345

choices.text: Occurs due to saponification of fats

questions.text: Which of these statements is true for Adipocere change after death? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occurs due to saponification of fats

 

Adipocere formation, also known as saponification, is a postmortem change characterized by the conversion of body fat into a waxy substance called adipocere. This process occurs due to the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of body fats, often in the presence of moisture and certain enzymes. Adipocere is most commonly formed in warm, moist, and anaerobic conditions, but not in extremely high temperatures or cold temperatures.

 

The formation of adipocere is an enzymatic process where body fats are broken down into fatty acids, which then combine with calcium ions to form soap-like compounds. This saponification process helps preserve the body tissues, preventing further decay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs in very high temperature: This option is incorrect because adipocere formation does not require very high temperatures. High temperatures favor mummification by accelerating dehydration rather than promoting saponification.

 

Option B. Occurs in cold temperature: Adipocere formation is less likely in cold conditions, as the enzymatic processes required for saponification are slowed down in low temperatures.

 

Option C. Occurs immediately after death: This is incorrect because adipocere formation takes time and does not occur immediately after death. The process can take weeks to months depending on environmental conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adipocere formation after death occurs due to the saponification of fats through an enzymatic process, primarily under warm, moist, and anaerobic conditions.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, following binge drinking and heavy meals, was brought to the emergency with sudden onset of severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Pneumomediastinum was present. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal perforation

 

Esophageal perforation, also known as Boerhaave syndrome, typically occurs after episodes of forceful vomiting or retching. The condition is characterized by a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus. The patient's history of binge drinking and heavy meals, followed by severe left-sided chest pain and pneumomediastinum, strongly indicates Boerhaave syndrome. The syndrome often presents with chest pain radiating to the shoulder, which aligns with the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mediastinal air leak: While mediastinal air leak might present with pneumomediastinum, it typically does not cause severe chest pain radiating to the shoulder. The history of binge drinking and heavy meals leading to this condition is less common.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity, usually due to a perforated abdominal organ. It generally presents with abdominal pain rather than chest pain and is less likely to be associated with the given clinical scenario.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer: Peptic ulcers usually cause abdominal pain and might lead to complications like bleeding or perforation, but they are not typically associated with pneumomediastinum or chest pain radiating to the shoulder in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome) can occur after episodes of forceful vomiting or retching, especially following binge drinking and heavy meals. It presents with severe chest pain and pneumomediastinum and requires prompt surgical intervention.

questions.text: A young boy developed keratitis after careless use of contact lenses due to unhygienic lens fluid. Microscopy showed an organism with spike-like pseudopodia. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthamoeba

 

Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba that is commonly found in water and soil. It can cause keratitis, particularly in individuals who use contact lenses with poor hygiene. Acanthamoeba keratitis is characterized by severe pain, redness, blurred vision, and the presence of corneal ulcers. Microscopic examination often reveals an organism with distinct spike-like pseudopodia, which is a key identifying feature of Acanthamoeba. This amoeba adheres to the corneal surface and invades the tissue, leading to infection and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Balantidium: Balantidium coli is a protozoan parasite known to cause intestinal infections (balantidiasis) primarily in humans and other primates. It does not cause keratitis or have spike-like pseudopodia.

 

Option C. Naegleria fowleri: Naegleria fowleri, also known as the "brain-eating amoeba," causes primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), a rare and often fatal brain infection. It does not typically present with keratitis or spike-like pseudopodia.

 

Option D. Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause a variety of infections, including conjunctivitis and other ocular infections, but it does not present with spike-like pseudopodia under microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For contact lens-related keratitis involving an organism with spike-like pseudopodia, Acanthamoeba is the most likely cause. It is essential to maintain proper hygiene with contact lenses to prevent such infections.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the OPD. She has Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characters. Her karyotype is 46XX. FSH is 5 and LH is 13. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian agenesis

 

The patient presents with primary amenorrhea, Tanner stage IV secondary sexual characteristics, a 46XX karyotype, and normal gonadotropin levels (FSH and LH). The development of secondary sexual characteristics indicates that the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis is functioning properly, which usually suggests normal ovarian function. Mullerian agenesis (also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is a condition where the uterus and part of the vaginal canal are absent, but ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics remain normal. This condition commonly presents with primary amenorrhea in individuals with a 46XX karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis refers to underdeveloped or non-functional gonads, leading to low estrogen levels and subsequent lack of secondary sexual characteristics. In this case, FSH and LH levels would typically be elevated, not normal.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: Kallmann syndrome is characterized by a lack of secondary sexual development due to low levels of gonadotropins (FSH and LH). This condition usually presents with delayed or absent puberty, unlike the normal Tanner stage IV development seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS): AIS involves individuals with a 46XY karyotype who are phenotypically female due to the body's inability to respond to androgens. This patient has a 46XX karyotype, ruling out AIS as a possible diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mullerian agenesis is a likely diagnosis in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual development, normal FSH/LH levels, and a 46XX karyotype.

choices.text: Transcervical resection of septum

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.

 

 

Other Options

 

Metroplasty is a type of unification procedures in mullerian anomalies

 

Option A. Jones metroplasty and Option C. Tompkins metroplasty are for septate uterus but are not preferred now. As now the treatment of choice is hysteroscopic resection of the septa.

 

Option B. Strassman metroplasty: Strassman metroplasty is for bicornuate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the best corrective procedure for a septate uterus to improve obstetric outcomes, as it does not scar the uterus and allows for future vaginal deliveries.

 

Ref: Page no 659, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby comes with a complaint of failure to thrive and presents with skin lesions that improve on a gluten-free diet. Which of the following option is true regarding the child’s condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A + B is correct

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition characterized by a hypersensitivity to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, bread, rye, and oats (collectively known as BROW). In individuals with celiac disease, ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, resulting in symptoms like chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and failure to thrive in children. Extra-intestinal manifestations include dermatitis herpetiformis, a skin condition characterized by itchy, blistering skin lesions commonly found on the elbows, knees, and other bony prominences.

 

Diagnosis of celiac disease often involves serological testing for anti-tissue transglutaminase (TTG) antibodies, which are usually elevated in affected individuals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Severe acute malnutrition: This condition causes failure to thrive due to inadequate nutritional intake but lacks the gluten sensitivity or specific skin lesions seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be considered in young children presenting with failure to thrive and characteristic skin lesions, especially when these symptoms improve with a gluten-free diet. Serological tests, including TTG, are crucial for confirming the diagnosis and should guide the clinical management of these patients.

questions.text: What is altered in thyroid profile throughout pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total T3 level

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the thyroid profile undergoes several changes due to physiological adaptations. One significant change is the increase in total T3 and T4 levels. This occurs because of the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), which increases the amount of bound thyroid hormones. Despite this increase, the levels of free T3 and free T4 remain relatively unchanged.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG): The production of TBG increases during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels. This leads to higher levels of total T3 and total T4.
  • Free T3 and Free T4: Despite the increase in total hormone levels, the free (unbound) hormone levels remain relatively stable. This is why free T3 and free T4 are preferred for thyroid function testing during pregnancy.
  • TSH: The levels of TSH may decrease slightly in the first trimester due to the thyrotropic effects of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), but they generally stabilize in the second and third trimesters.
  • Iodine requirement: Pregnancy increases the body's requirement for iodine by about 50%, due to increased renal clearance and fetal iodine needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Free T3 level: This remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Free T4 level: This also remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. TSH level: While TSH levels can decrease slightly in the first trimester, they typically stabilize throughout the rest of the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, total T3 and T4 levels increase due to elevated thyroid-binding globulin, while free T3 and T4 levels remain unchanged.

 

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma


Phacolytic glaucoma occurs when high intraocular pressure (IOP) is associated with a mature or hypermature cataract. The patient's right eye exhibits high IOP (50 mmHg), flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens, all of which are characteristic signs of phacolytic glaucoma. The leakage of lens material into the anterior chamber induces an inflammatory response, causing the observed clinical signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: This condition typically features a shallow or flat anterior chamber, which contrasts with the described deep anterior chamber. Therefore, it is not consistent with the clinical findings of this patient.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: This is usually a unilateral condition characterized by chronic inflammation, heterochromia (differences in iris color), and low-grade inflammation. It does not typically present with such high IOP or a cataractous lens as the primary issue.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: This type of glaucoma occurs due to lens-induced angle closure and is associated with a shallow anterior chamber. The patient, however, has a deep anterior chamber, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

A microscopic agglutination test is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Leptospira interrogans is a spirochete with hook-shaped ends found in water contaminated with animal urine, causes Leptospirosis.

 

Leptospirosis - Flulike symptoms, myalgias (classically of calves), jaundice, photophobia with conjunctival suffusion (erythema without exudate)

 

 

Weil disease (icterohemorrhagic leptospirosis) - severe form with jaundice and azotemia from liver and kidney dysfunction, fever, hemorrhage, and anemia.

 

Laboratory tests - Leptospirae can be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence.

 

Serotype-specific tests - Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)

 

  • Rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospirae - specific IgM antibodies in human sera.

 

Treatment - Penicillin or IV ceftriaxone

 

  • Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. Presents as stepwise increase in fever, abdominal pain, and constipation.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test used to diagnose rickettsial infections. Presents as fever, rash, and headache.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test, aka the Monospot test, used to detect heterophile antibodies in case of infectious mononucleosis, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).Presents as fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The microscopic agglutination test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in symptomatic individuals, especially those exposed to potentially contaminated water environments. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

 

  • The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. The most common complication associated with this condition is exposure keratopathy since the defect leaves the cornea exposed. If left untreated, it can lead to corneal ulceration.

 

CONGENITAL EYELID COLOBOMA

 

  • Can be unilateral or bilateral, involving one or all four lids.
  • The defect may vary from a small marginal notch to a full-thickness absence of the entire eyelid margin involving one-third to half of the eyelid.
  • The upper eyelid is commonly affected.
  • The most common site is the junction between the medial and middle third of the upper eyelid.
  • Eyelid colobomas represent an incomplete form of cryptophthalmos. Cryptophthalmos is a congenital condition in which there is a failure of differentiation of eyelid structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restricted eye movements: This is not a primary complication of eyelid coloboma. Restricted eye movements are more associated with orbital or extraocular muscle issues.

 

Option C. Diplopia: Diplopia, or double vision, is not a common complication of eyelid coloboma. It usually arises from misalignment of the eyes or neurological conditions.

 

Option D. Amblyopia: Amblyopia, or lazy eye, can occur due to vision deprivation in severe cases of eyelid abnormalities, but it is not the most common complication of eyelid coloboma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

choices.text: Z line, A band, H zone, I Band
A band, Z line, H zone, M Band
A band, I Band, Z line, H zone
Z line, A band, M Band, H zone

questions.text: Identify the correct labeling (A, B, C, D) in the given image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Z line, A band, H zone, I Band

 

  • A is the Z line: The light line marking the boundary between sarcomeres
  • B (A band): The darker, thicker region representing myosin filaments
  • C (H zone):  The lighter area between the A bands
  • D (I Band): The lighter area between Z lines containing actin filaments

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-month-old pregnant female presented with vivax malaria. She also had jaundice and confusion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quinine

 

Explanation

 

In the context of malaria treatment during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, safety of the medication is paramount.

 

For pregnant women in their first trimester with severe malaria (as indicated by symptoms like jaundice and confusion), quinine is the treatment of choice. Quinine is effective against severe malaria and is safer for use in early pregnancy compared to other options.

 

Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential hemolytic effects on the fetus, and doxycycline is also contraindicated due to risks of teratogenicity and dental staining.

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are generally avoided in the first trimester due to insufficient safety data, despite being the preferred treatment in non-pregnant adults and in later stages of pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Chloroquine + Primaquine: Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Doxycycline: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Artemisinin Combination Therapy: Not recommended in the first trimester due to insufficient safety data.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Quinine is the preferred treatment for severe malaria in pregnant women during the first trimester due to its safety profile compared to other antimalarial medications.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastroschisis

 

The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

 

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital birth defect characterized by a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilicus, which leads to the evisceration of the bowel loops which are not covered by a sac and are exposed to the external environment. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.

 

Congenital umbilical hernia: Umbilical hernia is a protrusion of the abdominal contents through a weakness in the umbilical ring, and ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital anomaly in which the urinary bladder is located outside the abdominal cavity.

 

 

Option B. Umbilical hernia: In case of umbilical hernia we do not usually see content of bowel coming out. Umbilical hernia is a cystic swelling which regresess when the baby is sleeping & appears during crying. No treatment is required for such condition.

 

Option D. Ectopia vesicae: Ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital malformation where the urinary bladder is located outside the lower abdominal wall. This condition is often associated with other abnormalities of the urinary tract and reproductive system. Ectopia vesicae is typically noticed at birth, and its severity can vary depending on the specific case

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital defect characterized by the herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus, without a protective sac covering the contents.

questions.text: What is the most sensitive investigation for parathyroid tumor imaging?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tc Sestamibi SPECT

 

Explanation:

 

For the imaging of parathyroid tumors, particularly in the context of hyperparathyroidism, several modalities can be employed. Each has its strengths and particular clinical situations where it might be the preferred choice.

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography technique also utilizes Technetium-99m sestamibi but combines it with CT imaging to provide three-dimensional imaging. This makes SPECT more sensitive than a plain sestamibi scan for locating parathyroid tumors, especially when they are ectopic or embedded deep within the neck or chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan: This is a nuclear medicine scan that uses a small amount of a radioactive compound , typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by active parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. While sensitive, it provides a two-dimensional view which can sometimes make precise localization of smaller or deeper tumors challenging.

 

Option C. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is useful for imaging the parathyroid glands due to its non-invasive nature and ability to detect lesions in real-time. It is particularly effective for glands located in typical positions near the thyroid. However, its effectiveness diminishes for ectopic glands or in obese patients where acoustic windows may be poor.

 

Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in complex cases, such as when other imaging modalities fail or in surgical planning. However, its sensitivity is generally lower than Sestamibi SPECT for detecting parathyroid adenomas, and it is less commonly used primarily due to higher costs and limited availability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting parathyroid tumors, particularly because it offers three-dimensional localization capabilities that can greatly assist surgeons in planning minimally invasive surgery.

questions.text: A Child presents with asymmetric crying face and inability to close the left eye as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve palsy

 

The clinical features shown in the image are characteristic of facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, also known as Bell's palsy.

 

Important features: 

 

  • Inability to close the eye (loss of orbicularis oculi function) 
  • Asymmetry of face 
  • Deviation of mouth to the normal side 
  • Loss of wrinkling and nasolabial fold on affected side This is due to damage to the facial nerve which supplies all muscles of facial expression including orbicularis oculi, buccinator, and other facial muscles.
  • The facial nerve emerges at the pontomedullary junction and exits through the stylomastoid foramen.
  • Facial nerve palsy can be idiopathic (Bell’s palsy) or secondary to infections (e.g., Herpes simplex, Ramsay Hunt syndrome), trauma, tumors, or stroke.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve palsy: 

 

  • Causes ptosis, an enlarged pupil, and an eye deviated "down and out" due to loss of extraocular muscle function.

 

Option C. Orbicularis oculi palsy:

 

  • This muscle is supplied by cranial nerve VII (facial nerve).
  • While paralysis of orbicularis oculi can cause incomplete eyelid closure, it does not affect other facial muscles as seen in facial nerve palsy.

 

Option D. Erb’s palsy

 

  • A brachial plexus injury (C5-C6), often seen in newborns after traumatic delivery.
  • Characterized by "waiter's tip" deformity (adducted, internally rotated arm with extended elbow and flexed wrist).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bell’s palsy - Loss of Wrinkling, Wide palpebral fissure, Whistling loss, loss of nasolabial fold and drooling of saliva

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oxygen therapy not useful? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Central respiratory depression

 

Explanation 

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression, as oxygen therapy will reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe further depressing the respiratory frequency and minute ventilation.



 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Because oxygen therapy can be crucial in severe asthma attacks where it helps alleviate hypoxia.

 

Option B. Acute myocardial infarction: As oxygen therapy is often used to increase oxygen delivery to the heart tissue, reducing ischemic damage during an acute myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Because oxygen therapy helps improve oxygenation in cases of pulmonary edema, especially if caused by heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression because it may reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe, potentially further depressing respiratory effort and overall ventilation.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein and positive India ink staining. What is likely causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Cryptococcus neoformans. The patient presents with signs of meningitis (fever, neck stiffness) and has a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile showing lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining.

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients and is diagnosed by the presence of encapsulated yeast cells seen on India ink staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumocystis jirovecii: This organism typically causes pneumonia rather than meningitis.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous meningitis usually presents with low glucose levels in the CSF, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus: Pneumococcal meningitis typically presents with a neutrophilic CSF rather than lymphocytic CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of meningitis in HIV patients, characterized by lymphocytic CSF, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining, which reveals encapsulated yeast cells. ​

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with complaints of fast breathing and distress. The image is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Croup

 

The case represents Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis). The X-ray shows the characteristic "steeple sign" - a tapering narrowing of the subglottic airway, which is pathognomonic for croup. The most common causative agent is parainfluenza virus. Treatment includes dexamethasone (steroids) and adrenaline nebulization. The condition presents with inspiratory stridor, barking cough, and respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute epiglottitis: Incorrect. Epiglottitis presents with "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray, not steeple sign. It is a more severe condition requiring immediate airway management.

 

Option C. Bronchiolitis: Incorrect. Bronchiolitis typically affects infants under 2 years and shows hyperinflation with patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray, not upper airway narrowing.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. The image clearly shows the characteristic steeple sign of croup.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) should be suspected in a child with barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and respiratory distress. The steeple sign on X-ray confirms the diagnosis. Management includes corticosteroids (dexamethasone) and nebulized epinephrine for severe cases.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for indirect inguinal hernia with mesh repair. The most commonly damaged nerve in this surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ilio-inguinal nerve

 

During open surgery for indirect inguinal hernia repair, particularly when mesh is used, the ilio-inguinal nerve is at significant risk of being damaged. This nerve runs through the inguinal canal, where it provides sensory innervation to the skin of the upper thigh, base of the penis, and scrotum in males, and the mons pubis and labia majora in females. Due to its anatomical position, it is prone to injury or entrapment during surgical procedures in this area, leading to postoperative pain or numbness in its distribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genitofemoral nerve: The genitofemoral nerve runs along the anterior surface of the psoas muscle and divides into genital and femoral branches. While it is in proximity, it is less likely to be damaged during typical open inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is located deeper and more laterally, beneath the inguinal ligament, and is not commonly affected during inguinal hernia repairs.

 

Option D. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve is located in the pelvis and provides motor and sensory innervation to the medial thigh. It is not involved in the inguinal region and is therefore unlikely to be damaged in hernia surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ilio-inguinal nerve is the most commonly damaged nerve during open surgery for indirect inguinal hernia repair, especially when mesh is used.

questions.text: Curtain falling sign is indicative of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinal detachment

 

The curtain falling sign is a classic symptom of retinal detachment (RD), specifically rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. In this condition, a tear or hole develops in the retina, allowing fluid to pass behind it and separate the retina from the underlying tissue. As the detached portion of the retina falls forward, it creates the perception of a curtain or shadow moving across the visual field, hence the term "curtain falling sign".

 

 

Treatment: The treatment for retinal detachment involves three primary steps:

 

  1. Subretinal Fluid (SRF) Drainage: This step involves removing the fluid that has accumulated beneath the retina to allow for proper reattachment.
  2. Opposition of Retinal and Scleral Surfaces: This is achieved through:
    • Vitrectomy: Removing vitreous gel to facilitate retinal manipulation.
    • Scleral Buckling (Encirclage): Placing a band around the eye to indent the sclera and close the retinal tear.
  3. Closure of the Retinal Break: This is done using:
    • Laser Photocoagulation: Applying laser energy to create a scar that seals the break.
    • Cryopexy: Using intense cold to freeze and seal the tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macular degeneration: This condition affects the central part of the retina (macula) and typically causes gradual vision loss or distortion in the central visual field, not a curtain-like shadow.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: This refers to the degeneration of the optic nerve fibers and usually results in pale optic discs and decreased visual acuity, but does not cause a curtain-like visual phenomenon.

 

Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This is inflammation of the front part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and typically causes pain, redness, and photophobia, but not a curtain-like visual symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

3 types of RD: Rhegmatogenous, Tractional and Exudative Retinal Detachment

 

1.   Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment:

  • Most common form, occurring when a tear or hole in the retina allows fluid to enter and accumulate under the retina, separating it from the underlying tissues.
  • Classical symptoms include visual flashes and floaters, which are due to the movement of the detached retina.
  • A "curtain falling" sign, where a section of the visual field appears to be shaded, is characteristic of this type.

 

2.  Tractional Retinal Detachment:

  • Occurs when fibrous or fibrovascular tissue, often resulting from proliferative diabetic retinopathy or other conditions, exerts traction on the retina, pulling it away from its underlying support tissue.

 

3.  Exudative Retinal Detachment:

  • Also known as serous retinal detachment, this type occurs without tears or breaks in the retina.
  • Fluid accumulates under the retina due to inflammation, injury, or vascular abnormalities causing leakage.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

 

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a significant cause of neonatal infections. It is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis globally. The bacteria exhibit beta-hemolysis on blood agar, characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells around the colonies, forming a clear zone. This hemolytic property helps in identifying and differentiating it from other types of Streptococci. GBS is biochemically identified as hippurate hydrolysis positive and CAMP test positive, both of which are unique to this bacterium. These tests confirm its identity and help in diagnosing infections caused by it.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Although Streptococcus agalactiae can occasionally cause infective endocarditis, it is not the most specific or common disease caused by this bacterium. Infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with other Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Option C. Dental caries: Dental caries are typically associated with Streptococcus mutans, not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. mutans plays a primary role in the development of tooth decay due to its ability to ferment sugars into acids, which demineralize the dental enamel.

 

Option D. Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis, commonly known as strep throat, is primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. pyogenes is known for causing various suppurative and non-suppurative infections, including pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

choices.text: Stop pyrazinamide and continue the rest of the drugs with kidney function test (KFT) monitoring.
Add uric acid-lowering drugs and continue antitubercular therapy (ATT) as such with liver function test (LFT) and KFT monitoring.
Continue all drugs and monitor serum uric acid level as well as LFT and KFT.
Stop all ATT drugs until laboratory values return to normal.

questions.text: A patient undergoing antitubercular therapy reports joint pain 10 days after initiation of treatment. Laboratory tests reveal normal AST and ALT levels, a serum creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL, and an elevated serum uric acid level of 10 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop pyrazinamide and continue the rest of the drugs with kidney function test (KFT) monitoring.

 

Pyrazinamide is known to increase uric acid levels as a side effect, and hyperuricemia can lead to joint pain, which is suggestive of gout. If the patient's liver function tests are within normal limits, but they have elevated serum uric acid levels and are experiencing joint pain, the likely culprit is pyrazinamide.

 

Option A is the best next step because:

 

  • Stopping pyrazinamide, which is most likely causing the hyperuricemia, should lead to a decrease in uric acid levels and an improvement in joint pain.
  • The rest of the antitubercular drugs can be continued to ensure the treatment of tuberculosis, with monitoring of kidney function tests to ensure the patient does not develop nephrotoxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Add uric acid-lowering drugs and continue antitubercular therapy (ATT) as such with liver function test (LFT) and KFT monitoring: Adding uric acid-lowering drugs might not be necessary immediately if pyrazinamide is discontinued. The primary goal is to identify and stop the drug causing the hyperuricemia.

 

Option C. Continue all drugs and monitor serum uric acid level as well as LFT and KFT: Continuing all drugs without modification might not address the underlying issue of hyperuricemia caused by pyrazinamide, potentially worsening the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Stop all ATT drugs until laboratory values return to normal: Stopping all ATT drugs would not be recommended as it could lead to the development of drug-resistant tuberculosis and could be harmful to the overall treatment of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyrazinamide can cause hyperuricemia and joint pain; stopping pyrazinamide while continuing other antitubercular drugs with monitoring is the appropriate management strategy.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the Chest X Ray?  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The chest X-ray shows a clear sign of air under the diaphragm, which is a classic radiographic finding indicating a hollow viscus perforation. This condition typically results from the perforation of any part of the gastrointestinal tract, such as the stomach, intestines, or colon, leading to the escape of air into the peritoneal cavity.

 

The key diagnostic clue in the X-ray is the presence of free air under the diaphragm, which appears as a crescent of radiolucency (dark area) beneath the dome of the diaphragm. This finding is an emergency and requires immediate medical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Everted hemidiaphragm: This condition would not present with free air under the diaphragm. Instead, it involves the abnormal elevation of one side of the diaphragm due to various causes such as phrenic nerve paralysis, but does not produce the characteristic air under the diaphragm seen in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Intestinal obstruction: While this condition can cause significant abdominal pain and distension, it does not typically result in the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray. Instead, intestinal obstruction is diagnosed via abdominal X-rays or CT scans showing dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels.

 

Option D. Hyperinflated lungs: This is usually seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and would show an increased lung volume and flattened diaphragms on the X-ray, but not free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray is a hallmark sign of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency

questions.text: What is the compression to ventilation ratio in an adult cardiac arrest patient in the presence of more than one rescuer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 30:2

 

In adult patients experiencing cardiac arrest, the recommended compression to ventilation ratio during CPR is 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers present. This ratio ensures that adequate chest compressions are delivered to maintain blood circulation while allowing time for sufficient ventilation to oxygenate the blood. The priority in adult CPR is effective chest compressions, which is why the ratio is set to 30 compressions for every 2 ventilations.

 

This ratio remains constant irrespective of whether there is one rescuer or more than one, ensuring consistency and simplicity during the resuscitation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For adult CPR, regardless of the number of rescuers, the compression to ventilation ratio should always be 30:2 to ensure effective circulation and oxygenation during cardiac arrest.

 

Additionally, For children with one rescuer, the ratio is 30 compressions to 2 ventilations (30:2); with two rescuers, the ratio is 15 compressions to 2 ventilations (15:2). For neonates, the ratio is 3 compressions to 1 ventilation (3:1).

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 
The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is characterized by hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet. Clinically, it often presents in infants around 3-6 weeks old with symptoms such as projectile vomiting (non-bilious), an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, and visible peristalsis. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis by showing a thickened pyloric muscle with measurements typically around 4 mm in thickness and 16 mm in length, which are diagnostic for CHPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, leading to symptoms like colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and “red currant jelly” stools (due to blood and mucus). It commonly presents with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and is typically not associated with a palpable olive-shaped mass or recurrent vomiting alone.

 

Option C. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that results from an incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. It may present with painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or signs of intestinal obstruction. The appearance on imaging is different, and it is not associated with the olive-shaped mass or the characteristic pyloric muscle thickening seen in CHPS.

 

Educational Objective:


CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: A couple presents to the OPD with their 4-year-old child who has self-mutilating behavior and poor growth. Identify the condition and enzyme involved in it: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HGPRT deficiency

 

The child’s symptoms of self-mutilating behavior and poor growth are characteristic of Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. This is a rare inherited disorder caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-Guanine Phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This enzyme is crucial in the purine salvage pathway, where it recycles purines into nucleotides rather than letting them degrade into uric acid.

 

When HGPRT is deficient, purines like hypoxanthine and guanine accumulate and are subsequently converted to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia and gout. The neurological manifestations, including self-mutilation and mental retardation, arise due to the deficiency in purine recycling, which is critical for proper brain function.

 

 

Note –

 

  • Xanthine oxidase is inhibited by allopurinol
  • The enzyme for salvage pathway is HGPRT

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogentisic Acid Oxidase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes Alkaptonuria, not Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome. Alkaptonuria is characterized by dark urine, ochronosis, and arthritis, not self-mutilation or poor growth.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine Hydroxylase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by intellectual disability and a musty body odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine, but not self-mutilation or gout.

 

Option D. Benzoyl Acidase: This is not a relevant enzyme in this context, and its mention is incorrect or misleading.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is caused by a complete deficiency of HGPRT, leading to self-mutilation, poor growth, hyperuricemia, and gout.

choices.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.
Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask.

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine in a neonate during resuscitation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/ minutes despite effective compression and ventilation.

 

If the heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation, consider administering epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation.

 

 

Note: Umbilical venous catheter is the preferred method of obtaining emergency vascular access in the delivery room.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.: if the heart rate is <100 bpm, we do bag and mask ventilation.

 

Option C. Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.: If the heart rate doesnot improve after 30 seconds of bag and mask ventilation, then we do ventilation corrective steps.

 

Option D. Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask: if the baby is not responding to bag and mask ventilation then check the heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epinephrine is administered in neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective positive-pressure ventilation and chest compressions.

questions.text: Varicella-zoster virus remains dormant in the: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dorsal root ganglion

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear.
  • The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised
  • The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventral root

  • It is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • The ventral root carries motor neurons, not sensory neurons, and VZV is not known to remain dormant in motor neurons or their associated structures.

 

Option B. Skin

  • It is not a site of viral latency.
  • While VZV does cause lesions in the skin, it does not remain dormant there.
  • Skin lesions occur during active infection when the virus reactivates and travels down sensory nerves to the skin.

 

Option C. Medulla oblongata

  • It is a part of the brainstem and is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • This virus specifically becomes dormant in the peripheral nervous system, not within the central nervous system structures such as the medulla oblongata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal root ganglion is the site of latency for the Varicella-zoster virus, which is important for understanding the pathogenesis of both primary varicella infection and reactivation as herpes zoster.

 

Reference

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13
