choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

 

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of esotropia and is associated with hypermetropia (farsightedness), not myopia (nearsightedness). The condition often presents in children around 2 to 3 years of age and is characterized by an inward turning of the eyes that is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation).

 

Types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common type of squint: True. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of esotropia seen in children. This type of squint is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation) and is associated with farsightedness (hypermetropia).

 

Option B. Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio: True. Miotics can be used to manage accommodative esotropia associated with a high AC/A ratio. Miotics reduce the need for accommodation, thereby reducing the associated esotropia.

 

Option D. Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles: True. The refractive type of accommodative esotropia can be fully corrected by using spectacles that correct the hypermetropia. These spectacles reduce the accommodative effort, thereby correcting the esotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 months

 

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months.

 

 

Fig: Bidextrous grasp approach to a dangling ring 4 months

 

Fine motor development:

 

  • Hands come together in midline by 5 months
  • Bidextrous Reach comes by 4 months
  • Tries to reach for object from both hand will be bidextrous approach & from one hand will be unidextrous approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bidextrous reach, where a baby uses both hands to reach out for objects, is typically achieved by 4 months of age.

questions.text: 35-year-old male presented with a swelling in the scrotum for which surgical removal was done as shown. Which of the following has the best prognosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seminoma

 

Seminoma is a type of testicular cancer that typically occurs in young and middle-aged men. It is known for its excellent prognosis, primarily because it is highly sensitive to radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Seminomas usually metastasize to the lymph nodes rather than spreading hematogenously, which makes them more manageable and treatable. The overall survival rate for patients with seminoma is very high due to these factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Teratoma: Teratomas are testicular tumors that can contain several types of tissues and may have variable behavior. While some teratomas can be benign, others can be malignant and more challenging to treat than seminomas.

 

Option C. Yolk sac tumor: Also known as endodermal sinus tumor, this is a malignant germ cell tumor more commonly seen in children. In adults, yolk sac tumors tend to have a poorer prognosis compared to seminomas.

 

Option D. Leydig cell Tumor: These tumors arise from the Leydig cells in the testes. While many Leydig cell tumors are benign, the malignant ones can be more aggressive and harder to treat than seminomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminomas have the best prognosis among testicular tumors due to their high sensitivity to radiotherapy and chemotherapy and their typically limited pattern of spread to lymph nodes.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation should be considered in cases where epistaxis is not controlled by trotters method or nasal packing.

 

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point.

 

Most common artery to be ligated for epistaxis is Sphenopalatine artery followed by internal maxillary artery, External carotid artery, Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of external carotid artery: The external carotid artery is a major artery that supplies blood to numerous facial structures, including the scalp, face, jaw, and more. Ligation of this artery is generally considered a more drastic measure and is typically reserved for severe cases where other specific arterial sources of bleeding have been ruled out or are inaccessible. It is much less selective than targeting the sphenopalatine artery and can lead to significant complications due to reduced blood flow to essential tissues.

 

Option B. Ligation of internal carotid artery: This option is generally not considered for epistaxis management due to the critical nature of the internal carotid artery, which primarily supplies blood to the brain. Ligation of this artery would pose a high risk of serious neurological deficits or stroke. It is a major artery and not a contributor to nasal bleeding; thus, it is not targeted in the treatment of epistaxis.

 

Option D. Ligation of maxillary artery: The maxillary artery is a major artery within the face that branches off the external carotid artery and gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery. While ligation of the maxillary artery is an option for severe epistaxis, it is less specific than targeting the sphenopalatine artery. The maxillary artery supplies areas broader than just the nasal cavity, including the maxilla, mandible, teeth, and parts of the face. Therefore, ligation of this artery is considered more invasive and has a higher risk of complications compared to the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

questions.text:
Examine the list of features given: [INICET MAY 2024]

 

  1. Delayed skin pinch
  2. Lethargy
  3. Thirst
  4. Sunken eyes
  5. Reduced Urine output

 

The features of some dehydration include:
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 3, 4

 

According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three types: no dehydration, some dehydration, and severe dehydration.

 

  • Some Dehydration: This condition is diagnosed when there are at least two of the following four signs: thirst, sunken eyes, delayed skin pinch (skin pinch goes back slowly), and restlessness or irritability. These signs indicate a moderate level of dehydration where the body is starting to show physical symptoms, but it has not yet progressed to a severe state.
  • In the question:
    • Delayed skin pinch (option 1) is one of the signs.
    • Thirst (option 3) is another sign.
    • Sunken eyes (option 4) is also a recognized sign of some dehydration.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option B, which includes all the relevant features (1, 3, and 4).

 

Other Options:

 

2: Lethargy is a sign of severe dehydration, not some dehydration, which makes this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • According to the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, dehydration is categorized into three levels based on specific signs and symptoms:

Iron deficiency anemia
Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with a history of fatigue and tiredness. On investigation, he was found to have Hb = 9 gm% and MCV =101 FL. Peripheral smear examination showed macrocytic RBC and hyper-segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic alcoholism

 

The given findings are suggestive of macrocytic anemia, which can be seen in chronic alcoholics.

 

Peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils are characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia.

 

 

Chronic alcoholics also have deficiency of folic acid due to:

 

  • Folate accumulation in the liver
  • Excessive urinary loss
  • Impaired folate metabolism
  • Chronic alcoholics frequently have insufficient dietary intake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead poisoning: Lead poisoning typically causes microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. Peripheral smear findings in lead poisoning include basophilic stippling of RBCs, not macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, which contrasts with the macrocytic RBCs and hyper-segmented neutrophils seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia generally presents with normocytic or slightly macrocytic RBCs, but not to the extent seen in megaloblastic anemia. Additionally, hyper-segmented neutrophils are not a typical feature of hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrocytic anemia with hyper-segmented neutrophils on a peripheral smear is characteristic of megaloblastic anemia, often due to folate deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics due to impaired folate metabolism and poor dietary intake.

questions.text: All of the following are true about neutrophil extracellular trap except:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phagocytosis is enhanced

 

Explanation:

 

Phagocytosis is enhanced: This statement is incorrect. NET formation does not directly enhance phagocytosis. Instead, it is a distinct mechanism where the neutrophil traps and kills pathogens extracellularly, without engulfing them through phagocytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are a defense mechanism employed by neutrophils to trap and kill extracellular pathogens. During NET formation, neutrophils undergo a process called NETosis, which involves chromatin decondensation and the release of DNA along with antibacterial enzymes into the extracellular space. This forms a mesh-like structure that can trap and kill bacteria.

 

Option A: Induced by sepsis: True. NETs are induced by various stimuli, including sepsis. In septicemia-like conditions, the presence of pathogens triggers the formation of NETs as a response to the infection.

 

Option C: Higher risk of SLE: True. NET formation also has some negative consequences. The exposure of nuclear antigens during NETosis can lead to an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The nuclear antigens released during NET formation can be recognized as "self" by the immune system, leading to the production of autoantibodies and the development of SLE.

 

Option D: Affected cell does not survive: True. In NET formation, the neutrophil undergoes a form of cell death called NETotic cell death. The affected neutrophil does not survive the process of NETosis, as it involves the release of its cellular contents, including DNA and enzymes. This process is sometimes referred to as "beneficial suicide" because the neutrophil sacrifices itself to create the extracellular trap that can capture and kill pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps are induced by sepsis, increase the risk of developing SLE due to exposure of nuclear antigens, and result in the death of the affected neutrophil, but they do not enhance phagocytosis.
